title: Leintwardine Walks

images.title: Row17 / Teme Bridge at Leintwardine
images.caption: Teme Bridge at Leintwardine. A bridging point of the River Teme since at least Roman times. A fine five-span structure dating back to the 18th century.

images.title: Peter Evans / River Teme, Leintwardine
images.caption: The River Clun joins the Teme at this bend in the river.

images.title: Peter Evans / The Sun Inn, Leintwardine
images.caption: The Sun Inn, Leintwardine. Historic old bar-parlour pub

images.title: Peter Evans / Brockley meadow along the River Teme, Leintwardine.
images.caption: Brockley meadow along the River Teme.

images.title: Peter Evans / Leintwardine village from Church Hill
images.caption: View from Church Hill looking West over the snowy village.

images.title: Peter Evans / Jay Bridge
images.caption: Jay Bridge over the Clun River West of Leintwardine

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Beef cattle in summer meadow
images.caption: Beef cattle in summer meadow. The hills around Clungunford can be seen in the distance.

description: This small village in North Herefordshire sits in a pleasant rural location close to the Shropshire border. There's some nice trails along the two local rivers and some interesting historical sites in this former Roman settlement. This circular walk takes you along the river Clun to Jay Bridge, to the west of the village. It then follows country lanes through the surrounding countryside before passing through the village and paying a visit to the River Teme. On the way you'll visit the point where the two rivers converge and enjoy views of the historic Leintwardine Bridge which dates from the 18th century and spans the Teme. There's also a climb to Church Hill where you can enjoy fine views over the village and surrounding countryside.
